newsitem.title: CHINA: HK unveils arrangements for next legislative poll.
newsitem.headline: HK unveils arrangements for next legislative poll.

text.p: Hong Kong on Tuesday unveiled plans for its first legislative election under Chinese rule which will adopt proportional representation and cut the voting population for some polls.

Under the plan, formulated by Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa's cabinet, 20 seats of the 60-strong legislature will be directly elected from geographical constituencies by proportional representation, secretary for Constitutional Affairs Nicholas Ng said.

"We anticipate that the first Legislative Council election will be held in the second quarter of next year," he said. Hong Kong will be divided into five constituencies, each with three to five seats depending on the size of population, he told a news conference.
This contrasted with arrangements in the last legislative election in 1995 where the territory was divided into 20 smaller geographical consistencies, each with one seat.

Under the new system, pro-democracy parties are unlikely to repeat their strong 1995 showing in which they won the largest bloc of seats in the ousted colonial assembly, which was replaced by a provisional chamber upon Hong Kong's handover.
The Democratic Party condemned the proposals as "targeted at democrats".

In a statement, party chairman Martin Lee said: "Broadly speaking, it is clear that the entire point of all of the changes is to ensure that the Democratic Party -- which won the largest number of seats in the 1991 and 1995 legislative elections -- will be reduced to a tiny minority in the council. This represents the beginning of the 'Singaporisation' of Hong Kong, where there are so-called 'elections' -- but the results are always what the government wants."
A recent poll conducted by the party last month showed 41.4 percent of Hong Kong people indicated they do not want to change the existing voting system, the statement said.
But Ng defended the plan, saying there had been criticism the former system yielded results that could not reflect the public's view.
"The basic idea for the proportional representation system is that electors' views can be fairly reflected in the election results and thereby in the allocation of seats," he said.
"We think that this particular method will be able to yield fair and open results," he said.
China recovered Hong Kong at midnight on June 30, ending 156 years of British colonial rule.
It scrapped the territory's legislature that was elected in 1995 and replaced it with an appointed provisional chamber which operates until the new legislature is elected.
Under the new electoral plans, functional constituencies will return 30 seats, of which 21 will be for the 21 existing functional constituencies and the remaining nine for new ones.
Voters in most functional constituencies will be corporate bodies instead of employees of companies in those sectors, as in the 1995 elections.

"Reshaping of the functional constituencies, particularly the nine new functional constituencies in the current makeup, would confine the voters...to the corporation-based or organisation-based (system) or membership of professional bodies," Ng said.
He acknowledged the new arrangements would mean a reduction in the number of voters in the functional constituency polls.

But he added the largest number of voters would fall in the geographical constituencies, where electors were expected to increase. "Every year, we have additional voters registered under the geographic set-up," he said.
In the new electoral plan, another 10 legislators will be elected from an election committee formed with 800 permanent Hong Kong residents from different sectors, Ng said.
The elective college will include all provisional legislators and Hong Kong deputies to China's National People's Congress, or the Chinese parliament.
Ng said he aimed to submit a bill covering the electoral arrangements into the provisional legislature for first reading before the end of August.
